metadata.title: Facile immobilization of base ionic liquids onto graphene oxide in water at room temperature as heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification

Table 6 Entry Catalysts Catalyst(mg) nMeOH/nEC EC(mmol) T(K) T(h) P(Mpa) Con.% Yield% Ref. 1 ILs on MCM-41 200 8:1 25 453 4 1.17 78 76 [39] 2 ILs on silica 200 8:1 25 453 6 1.34 81 67 [40] 3 ILs on MCF 500 10:1 30 338 5 AP 85 83 [25] 4 IGO-W 100 10:1 30 353 6 AP 93 92 This work Facile immobilization of base ionic liquids onto graphene oxide in water at room temperature as heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification Bing Xue Jing Wu Na Liu Xingxing Zhu Yongxin Li ⁎ Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou 213164, China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou 213164 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The basic ionic liquids (ILs) 1-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide was immobilized on the surface of graphene oxide (GO) by silanization with the siloxane-terminated ILs in water at room temperature for the first time. The catalytic performances of the GO grafted with the basic ILs were investigated in transesterification reactions. The high catalytic activities and excellent product selectivities of GO grafted with the basic ILs in transesterification reactions can be ascribed to the large amount of ILs on the GO surface. The high dispersibility of GO in water prompted our investigation of grafting of a basic ILs on a GO surface. This method is the most efficient, simple, and green approach for the immobilization of ILs reported to date. Keywords Graphene oxide Ionic liquids Immolibilization Transesterification 1 Introduction Transesterification is one of the most important transformations in organic synthesis, and is generally performed using basic catalysts [1]. Conventionally, NaOH and KOH have been used as effective homogeneous catalysts for transesterification [2]. These compounds have high catalytic activities, but because of issues such as equipment corrosion, and catalyst separation and post-processing, they do not meet the criteria for green and sustainable catalysts. Various heterogeneous catalysts such as basic metal oxides [3,4], basic anion-exchange resins [5], and hydrotalcite [6] have been used in transesterification to overcome these problems. However, most of these catalysts have low catalytic activities and therefore require harsh reaction conditions, and this limits their use in transesterification. Ionic liquids (ILs) are widely used in catalysis because of their special properties [7,8]. Excellent performances have been obtained in transesterification reactions catalyzed by basic ILs [9,10]. However, because ILs separation is difficult, their immobilization on solid supports, e.g., mesoporous molecular sieves such as MCM-41 and SBA-15, is desirable [11,12]. However, poor hydrothermal stability, mass-transfer resistance during reactions, and the high preparation costs of mesoporous molecular sieves severely hinder their use in heterogeneous catalysis. The development of more efficient and sustainable supports for IL immobilization is necessary because of the increasing focus on the use of immobilized ILs in heterogeneous catalysis. Recently, graphene and graphene oxide (GO) have attracted attention in heterocatalysis because of their unusual two-dimensional structures, huge surface areas, and other excellent properties [13–16]. The presence of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of GO makes it a promising candidate for IL immobilization for heterogeneous catalysis. GO has significant advantages over mesoporous molecular sieves as a support for IL immobilization, e.g., excellent hydrothermal stability, a high surface area, and low-cost large-scale production. Perhaps most importantly, there are almost no barriers to substrate transfer. GO therefore provides a novel support for heterogeneous catalysts. ILs have been grafted on GO surfaces based on a nucleophilic ring-opening reaction between the epoxy groups of GO and amine groups of an amine-terminated IL [17]. However, GO has few epoxide groups; this limits the amount of IL that can be grafted on GO and hinders the use of these immobilized ILs in catalysis. Recently, it has been reported that ILs can be immobilized on the surface of GO via silanization of GO with siloxane-terminated ILs [18–21]. However, almost all the reported functionalizations of GO with siloxanes were performed in organic solvents, at high temperatures, and under the protection of an inert gas. The dispersibility of GO in most organic solvents is poor because the oxygen-containing groups render the GO sheets hydrophilic [22]. Furthermore, the functionalization of GO at high temperatures always results in agglomeration of GO nanoparticles, which decreases the amount of available oxygen-containing functional groups. This influences the effect of GO functionalization. In IL immobilization on the surface of GO, the dispersibility of GO in the solvent is one of the key factors determining the amount of IL grafted and the catalytic performance of the immobilized IL. GO has excellent hydrophilicity because of its oxygen-containing groups [23]. Water, in which GO can form a stable colloid, is therefore the most suitable solvent for dispersing GO. Furthermore, water is a green solvent and its use satisfies the increasing demand for green and sustainable catalysis. However, the functionalization of GO with siloxane-terminated ILs in water has not yet been reported because most siloxanes are sensitive to water. Recently, we found that the basic ILs 1-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide ([SmIm]OH) was less sensitive than (3-chloropropyl)trimethoxysilane to water. As shown in Fig. 1 , [SmIm]OH is not hydrolyzed in water at pH 10 and room temperature. This prompted us to develop a novel and facile method for immobilizing [SmIm]OH on the surface of GO in water. The immobilization of [SmIm]OH on the surface of GO in water proceeded efficiently at room temperature. The GO grafted with [SmIm]OH gave excellent catalytic performances in transesterification reactions. In the present study, we prepared GO grafted with [SmIm]OH (as shown in Scheme 1 ) in water at room temperature and investigated its catalytic performance in transesterification. We believe that this method is the most efficient, simple, and green approach for the immobilization of ILs on GO developed to date. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of graphite oxide Graphite oxide was prepared from natural graphite by the modified Hummers’ method [24]. In a typical process, 69mL of concentrated H2SO4 were added to a mixture of 3g of graphite and 1.5g NaNO3, cooled to 273K and stirred for 30min. Subsequently, 9g of KMnO4 was added slowly over 20min, and the obtained mixture was stirred for 2h at a constant temperature below 278K. The mixture was warmed to 308K and stirred for 1h, at which time 138mL of de-ionized (DI) water was added slowly to the reaction mixture and stirred for another 30min. External heating was introduced to maintain the reaction temperature at 371K. Finally, the mixture was poured into a beaker containing 420mL of DI and stirred vigorously. About 15mL of 30% hydrogen peroxide was subsequently added until the color changed to bright yellow. The suspension was filtered and washed successively with 200mL of 10% HCl for 3 times. The filter residue was vacuum-dried overnight at room temperature and graphite oxide was obtained. 2.2 Preparation of base ILs [SmIm]OH The base ILs 1-(trimethoxysilyl) propyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide was prepared using a previously reported method [25]. In brief, 18.6mL of (3-chloropropyl) trimethoxysilan and 8.0mL of N-methylimidazole were mixed well and refluxed at 353K for 48h. The resultant mixture was washed with ether to remove the unreacted impurities. Then, the solution was dried under vacuum to remove excess ether. Finally, a viscous and light yellow ILs was obtained and denoted as [SmIm]Cl. Then, 3g of [SmIm]Cl was added into 100mL of ethanol solution containing KOH (0.2mol/L). The mixture was stirred for 3h, and subjected to filtration to remove white precipitate and rotary evaporation. The resultant white ILs prepared through the ion exchange method was 1-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide (denoted as [SmIm]OH). 2.3 Immobilization of base ILs [SmIm]OH onto GO The basic ILs was immobilized on the GO surface as follows. GO (0.2g) was added to deionized water (200mL) containing [SmIm]OH (1.0g). The mixture was ultrasonicated three times; each ultrasonication lasted for ca. 30min. The well-dispersed mixture was stirred for 48h at room temperature and filtered, rinsed by deionized water for several times, and subsequently dried overnight under 353K. Finally, the obtained immobilized ILs was denoted as IGO-W. Furthermore, the effects of mass ratio of GO to [SmIm]OH on the catalytic performances of IGO-W were also investigated by varying the amount of ILs from 0.5g to 1.5g. 2.4 Characterizations Elementary analysis was performed with EA2400 II (PerkinElmer) instrument. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were collected in transmission mode from KBr pellets at room temperature on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer with a resolution of 4cm−1, using 32 scans per spectrum in the region of 400–4000cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a Perkin-Elmer PHI 5000C spectrometer working in the constant analyzer energy mode with Mg Ka radiation as the excitation source. Structural analysis of the samples was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (XRD). Raman spectra were recorded on a Raman spectrometer (Jobin Yvon Lab Ram HR evolution) using 532nm line as an excitation source. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were obtained using a Park Scientific CP-Research model (VEECO) with a Si tip in the tapping mode. 2.5 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests for the transesterification of ethylene carbonate (EC) with methanol were conducted in a two-neck round bottomed flask (50mL). Methanol and EC (a total volume of 15mL) were mixed well. Then 0.1g of IGO-W sample was added into the mixture and the tests were performed at 353K for 6h. After the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged and analyzed by GC–MS. The filtered catalyst was washed with water for two times, dried overnight, and then investigated for its subsequent running. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterizations The elemental compositions of pure GO and IGO-W are given in Table 1 . The nitrogen content of the IGO-W sample was 6.05%. This is the most direct evidence for the successful immobilization of [SmIm]OH on the GO surface. The results indicate that [SmIm]OH was immobilized on the GO surface and the amount of grafted [SmIm]OH was about 2.16mmol/g. The presence of nitrogen species was confirmed using FT-IR spectroscopy. The FT-IR spectra in Fig. 2 show that the bare GO gave four intense peaks, at 1720, 1614, 1230, and 1070cm−1, corresponding to the stretching vibrations of the CO, CC, COH, and CO groups of GO, respectively. This is in agreement with the previously reported spectra of GO-based materials [26]. After [SmIm]OH immobilization, the peaks from the CO and CC groups were unchanged, but the intensities of the peaks corresponding to COH and CO groups decreased significantly. Additionally, two weak peaks, at 2941 and 2883cm−1, were observed in the spectrum of the IGO-W sample; these correspond to symmetric and asymmetric vibrations, respectively, of the CH bonds of alkyl chains [27]. The IGO-W sample also gave an additional peak at 1340cm−1, which is ascribed to symmetric CN stretching of the imidazole ring [28]. The new peak at 1089cm−1 was assigned to the SiOC stretching vibration [29]. These peaks also confirmed that [SmIm]OH was successfully immobilized on the GO surface via condensation between the CO groups of GO and the terminal siloxanes of [SmIm]OH. XPS was used to examine the surfaces of the GO and IGO-W samples. The XPS survey spectrum of GO showed that the bare GO surface consisted of carbon and oxygen (Fig. 3 a). For the IGO-W sample, nitrogen and silicon were detected in addition to carbon and oxygen (Fig. 3b), indicating that [SmIm]OH had been grafted on the GO surface. Two small peaks in the XPS survey spectrum of IGO-W were also observed, at about 200 and 16eV; these should be assigned to Cl 2p1 and Cl 3s, respectively [30,31]. These could arise from the residues of hybrochloric acid during the preparation of synthesis of graphite oxide and the incomplete ion exchange between [SmIm]Cl and KOH during the preparation of base ILs [SmIm]OH. The detailed distribution of carbon species was clarified by deconvolution of the C1s spectra of GO and IGO-W. The C1s spectrum of GO was deconvoluted into four peaks centered at 284.7, 285.4, 286.7, and 288.4eV, assignable to CC, COH, epoxide, and carbonyl (CO and OCOH) [32], respectively (Fig. 4 a). A peak at 285.9eV was observed in the C1s spectrum of IGO-W, corresponding to CN bonds [33] (Fig. 4b). The intensities of the peaks associated with CO groups were lower in the IGO-W spectrum than in the GO spectrum. This suggests that some of the CO groups in GO underwent reactions during immobilization of [SmIm]OH. The CO peak in the IGO-W spectrum was significantly weaker than that in the GO spectrum (Fig. 4b). These results are in agreement with the FT-IR results shown in Fig. 2. The results indicate that GO was reduced in the basic solution during the immobilization process [34]. The XRD patterns in Fig. 5 show that the sharp diffraction peak at 2θ=10.2° from the (001) plane of pristine GO broadened and almost completely disappeared in the pattern of the IGO-W sample. This shows that during silylation, the regularly aggregated GO sheets were efficiently exfoliated to basal sheets bridged with siloxanes groups, corresponding to transformation from a crystalline to an amorphous state [35]. Raman spectroscopy is widely used to investigate disorder in carbon-based materials. Fig. 6 shows Raman spectra of the GO and IGO-W samples. The two samples show peaks at ca. 1363 and 1594cm−1, which are attributed to the D band (vibrations of sp3-hybridized carbon atoms in defects or disordered carbon), and G band (vibrations of sp2-hybrized carbon atoms in graphitic hexagonal lattices), respectively [36]. The intensities of the Raman bands from IGO-W were appreciably lower than those of pure GO. The intensity ratio of the D to G peaks (ID/IG) for IGO-W was ca. 1.20, much higher than that for GO (1.07). This indicates that the percentage of sp2 carbon species decreased because of formation of disordered sp3 carbon atoms after immobilization of the basic ILs. The increase in the percentage of sp3 carbon species in the IGO-W sample can be ascribed to the carbon atoms in [SmIm]OH. This is in agreement with previous reports [37,38]. Fig. 7 shows atomic force microscopy (AFM) images, and cross-sectional analyses along the lines in the AFM images, of the GO and IGO-W samples. It is clear that the bare GO (Fig. 7A) and IGO-W (Fig. 7B) samples were both well dispersed. The average thickness of the IGO-W sample, calculated from the height profile of the AFM image, is about 2.0nm. This is clearly larger than the thickness of the bare GO sheets, i.e., 0.80nm. This can be attributed to attachment of the basic ILs [29,32]. Attachment of the basic ILs could also prevent GO sheet agglomeration. All the results described above confirm that [SmIm]OH was successfully immobilized on the GO surface in water at room temperature. This is attributed to the stability of [SmIm]OH in water and the excellent dispersibility of GO in water. Almost all siloxanes are sensitive to water, and are immediately hydrolyzed to form stable silanol groups. However, the basic ILs [SmIm]OH is stable in water at room temperature and no hydrolysis was observed, as shown in Fig. 1. Unlike siloxanes, [SmIm]OH is an ionic compound, and siloxane hydrolysis is effectively prevented by the solvent effect of water. [SmIm]OH can therefore be immobilized on the GO surface. Water is the most suitable solvent for GO dispersion, and GO can form a stable colloid in water. The dispersibility of GO is one of the main reasons for the increased amount of grafted ILs during ILs immobilization on the GO surface. Also, the immobilization of [SmIm]OH on the GO surface in water proceeds efficiently at room temperature. The low temperature effectively avoids agglomeration of GO nanoparticles, which can decrease the amount of available oxygen-containing functional groups. 3.2 Catalytic performance The transesterification of EC with methanol was performed using IGO-W as the catalyst; the results are shown in Table 2 . The yield of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was low, i.e., 3%, when pure GO was used as the catalyst (entry 1). This indicates that pure GO has almost no catalytic activity in the transesterification of EC with methanol under these conditions. The IGO-W sample gave an excellent catalytic performance in the transesterification of EC with methanol: 93% conversion of EC and 99% selectivity for DMC (entry 2). These results suggest that the IGO-W sample prepared by grafting [SmIm]OH on the GO surface in water at room temperature is an effective catalyst for the transesterification of EC with methanol. The effects of the GO:[SmIm]OH mass ratio on the catalytic performance of IGO-W were also investigated; the results are shown in Table 2. The performance of the IGO-W prepared using 1.0g of the basic ILs was better than that of IGO-W prepared using a smaller amount of [SmIm]OH (entry 3). However, there was no obvious improvement in the catalytic performance when IGO-W was prepared using 1.5g of the basic ILs (entry 4). The optimum amount of [SmIm]OH for preparation of the IGO-W catalyst was therefore 1.0g. [SmIm]OH immobilization on the GO surface was also performed in methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol (EG), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) at room temperature; the corresponding samples are denoted by IGO-M, IGO-E, IGO-EG, and IGO-DMSO. The catalytic performances of these catalysts in the transesterification of EC with methanol are also shown in Table 2. The catalytic activity of IGO-M in this transesterification (entry 5) was significantly lower than that of the IGO-W sample. The catalytic performance of IGO-DMSO in EC transesterification with methanol was much poorer than those of the other IGO samples (entry 8). The elemental analysis results for the IGO samples prepared in different solvent are shown in Table 3 . The nitrogen contents of the IGO samples differed significantly. The nitrogen content of the IGO-DMSO sample was considerably lower than that of the IGO-W sample. This indicates that the amount of grafted ILs on IGO-DMSO was lower than that on IGO-W, corresponding to the catalytic performances of these samples in EC transesterification with methanol. The dispersion degrees of GO in these solvents are different [22]. The dispersibility of GO in most organic solvents is poor because the oxygen-containing groups render the GO sheets hydrophilic. GO shows maximum dispersibility in water, therefore water was used for grafting the basic ILs on the GO surface. An important property of a heterogeneous catalyst is that it can be conveniently recycled and reused. The data in Table 4 show that IGO-W was reused at least six times without a significant decrease in the EC conversion and selectivity for DMC. Elemental analysis showed that the nitrogen content of IGO-W was almost the same (5.94%) after being reused six times, implying excellent stability against ILs leaching because of covalent bonding between the ILs and the GO sheets. The bands in the FT-IR spectrum of IGO-W after six runs were the same (including those assigned to vibrations of CH2 groups, imidazole, and COSi) as those in the spectrum of fresh IGO-W (Fig. 2), suggesting that there was no significant loss of the grafted basic ILs during recycling. This confirms that IGO-W can be used as an effective catalyst for the transesterification of EC with methanol. The versatility of IGO-W in transesterification reactions was investigated based on the reactions of EC and propylene carbonate (PC) with low-carbon fatty alcohols in 1:10 molar ratios; the results are summarized in Table 5 . The conversion of PC with a low-carbon fatty alcohol was lower than that of EC (entries 2 and 6). The transesterification of a cyclic carbonate with a low-carbon fatty alcohol is a typical nucleophilic addition reaction. The basic sites on IGO-W act as sites for adsorption and activation of low-carbon fatty alcohol molecules, yielding highly active low-carbon fatty alcohol anions. Because of steric hindrance, nucleophilic addition of the anion to PC is more difficult than nucleophilic addition to EC, therefore a lower yield is obtained in the transesterification of PC with a low-carbon fatty alcohol. The conversion of EC or PC decreased with increasing number of carbon atoms in the fatty alcohol chain (entries 3 and 8). This is also ascribed to steric hindrance by low-carbon fatty alcohols with long carbon chains. Increasing the reaction temperature from 353 to 363K has only a slight effect on the EC conversion. However, prolonging the reaction or increasing the temperature facilitated catalytic transesterification of PC with low-carbon fatty alcohols and higher conversions were achieved (entries 9–11). The data in Table 6 show the performances of various reported heterogeneous catalysts in the transesterification of EC with methanol. The DMC yields show that the catalytic activity of IGO-W is clearly higher than those of the other catalysts listed in Table 6. Also, the reaction reported in this work proceeds under atmospheric pressure at 353K, whereas the reactions in entries 1–3 were performed under high pressure, high temperature, or with a high catalyst dosage. Based on the corresponding DMC yields and the reaction conditions, the IGO-W catalyst is more efficient than previously immobilized ILs catalysts in the transesterification of EC with methanol. 4 Conclusions In summary, a basic ILs was immobilized on the surface of GO in water at room temperature by silanization of GO with a siloxane-terminated ILs, namely [SmIm]OH. The excellent catalytic performance of the IGO-W catalyst in transesterification indicated that immobization of the basic ILs on the GO surface was successful. The outstanding dispersibility of GO in water is one of the key factors in increasing the amount of grafted basic ILs and improving the catalytic performance of the immobilized basic ILs. This is the most efficient, simple, and green approach for immobilization of ILs developed to date. coredata.dc:description: The basic ionic liquids (ILs) 1-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl-3-methylimidazolium hydroxide was immobilized on the surface of graphene oxide (GO) by silanization with the siloxane-terminated ILs in water at room temperature for the first time. The catalytic performances of the GO grafted with the basic ILs were investigated in transesterification reactions. The high catalytic activities and excellent product selectivities of GO grafted with the basic ILs in transesterification reactions can be ascribed to the large amount of ILs on the GO surface. The high dispersibility of GO in water prompted our investigation of grafting of a basic ILs on a GO surface. This method is the most efficient, simple, and green approach for the immobilization of ILs reported to date.
coredata.dc:title: Facile immobilization of base ionic liquids onto graphene oxide in water at room temperature as heterogeneous catalysts for transesterification
